This vehicle is typically larger and slower moving than passenger cars. Its presence indicates that there might be construction activity nearby. The future driving behavior of the ego vehicle may involve maintaining a safe following distance, being prepared for potential stops or slow movement of the construction vehicle, and increased situational awareness to anticipate any merging construction traffic or changes in the flow of traffic due to construction work.

Buses typically make regular stops to pick up and drop off passengers and may pull over to the side of the road at designated bus stops. driving_suggestion: Maintain a safe following distance from the construction truck to allow time for reaction to any potential sudden stops. Observe the overhead directional signs to stay in the appropriate lane for the intended route. Continue to monitor the surroundings for any additional road users or changes in traffic conditions. Be prepared for the possibility of the truck slowing down or stopping suddenly due to its active role on the road. If the ego vehicle plans to take an upcoming exit or needs to perform a lane change as indicated by the overhead sign, initiate the lane change procedure safely and well in advance, using turn signals to indicate intended movements to other road users. Prepare to change lanes if the truck's behavior indicates a stop or slow down significantly. Monitor the adjacent lane for a safe gap to merge if a lane change becomes necessary. Be alert for any changes in traffic flow due to the indicated junction ahead.
